# Business Rules and Domain Logic for shoppingMallAi

## Introduction
All system-wide and domain-specific business rules, validation logic, and lifecycle constraints guiding shoppingMallAi operations are specified below using EARS (Easy Approach to Requirements Syntax) for clarity, testability, and unambiguous backend implementation. Business requirements are comprehensive and actionable, covering all roles (customer, seller, administrator) and supporting full enforcement, auditability, and business integrity.

> Business requirements only. Technical implementation (architecture, schemas, APIs, etc.) is at development team discretion.

Reference for domain and workflow boundaries:  
- [User Roles and Authentication Requirements](./02-user-roles-and-authentication.md)  
- [Core Functional Requirements](./03-core-functional-requirements.md)  
- [Discounts, Payments and Financial Flows](./06-discounts-payments-and-financial-flows.md)  
- [Product & Catalog Management](./04-product-and-catalog-management.md)  
- [Performance, Error Handling, and Usability](./11-performance-error-handling-and-usability.md)  

## 1. Cross-cutting Business Rules

### Unique Identity and Reference Integrity
- THE system SHALL guarantee globally unique identifiers for every user, seller, product, order, coupon, and payment throughout entity lifecycle.
- WHEN an entity is created, THE system SHALL check for identifier collisions and reject non-unique references, returning a user-facing message indicating conflict.
- IF duplicate identifiers are detected, THEN THE system SHALL block creation, escalate to administrators, and require corrective review.

### Role-based Access and Action Authorization
- WHERE user role restricts operations (e.g., only sellers may update product pricing, only administrators may approve sellers), THE system SHALL check permissions referencing the [Role-Based Permissions Matrix](./02-user-roles-and-authentication.md) before allowing each business function.
- IF a user attempts an unauthorized action, THEN THE system SHALL deny the request, log the attempt with full context (user, role, timestamp, attempted action), and show a precise error message referencing insufficient permissions.
- WHEN a user is marked suspended, banned, or has not met tenure or verification policies, THE system SHALL restrict access to all actions not permitted by status until eligibility is restored.
- WHERE an administrator changes role assignments or updates platform-wide permissions, THE system SHALL enforce changes immediately or upon next session, according to policy, and log the event.

### Data Auditability and Non-repudiation
- THE system SHALL record all creation, modification, and deletion of critical business entities (order, inventory, reviews, payouts, coupons, attachments) as audit events, with actor, action, timestamp, and before/after state.
- WHEN a critical business event occurs (compliance, moderation, legal, financial, or workflow-impacting change), THE system SHALL snapshot the prior state and ensure traceability for regulatory retention period.
- IF an audit or data integrity violation is detected (e.g., unauthorized edit, unexpected rollback, tampering), THEN THE system SHALL flag, mark, and escalate the record for risk review, locking further changes as per [Performance, Error Handling, and Usability](./11-performance-error-handling-and-usability.md).

### Anti-Fraud Controls and Abuse Prevention
- WHEN indicators of fraud or abuse (multiple failed payments, coupon redemption surges, cancellation spikes, identity patterns, or statistically abnormal behavior) are detected, THE system SHALL flag suspicious accounts, orders, or actions, suspend or restrict automatically per escalation policy, and log a risk incident for administrative review.
- WHERE an automated risk trigger is escalated, THE system SHALL allow administrators to review, lift, or extend restrictions with an audit record.

---

## 2. Domain-specific Validation

### Registration and Account Management
- WHEN a user registers, THE system SHALL validate unique email and mobile, enforce minimum password requirements, apply registration flow matching user role, and confirm terms and privacy acceptance.
- IF an existing email or phone is found during registration, THEN THE system SHALL block registration, message the cause, and provide password reset or sign-in guidance.
- WHERE registration uses OAuth/external provider, THE system SHALL map to a unique internal user and prevent account duplication/merge errors per [User Roles and Authentication Requirements](./02-user-roles-and-authentication.md).
- WHEN a seller registers, THE system SHALL require additional identity verification (business documentation, bank, contact), mark the user as 'pending verification', and suspend commerce until administrator approval.
- WHEN an account is suspended, banned, or withdrawn, THE system SHALL enforce logical deletion/anonymization for personal data, retaining legally necessary records only.

### Seller Verification and Product Management
- WHEN a seller attempts to create, update, or delete a product, THE system SHALL validate all business-required fields: title, price, category, inventory, main image, description, variant/options, and compliance flags.
- IF a prohibited, restricted, or incomplete listing is submitted, THEN THE system SHALL block the listing/update and return an actionable, domain-specific error message.
- WHERE a product has options or variants, THE system SHALL require unique SKUs, independence of inventory per variant, and enforce all mapping and integrity constraints as in [Product & Catalog Management](./04-product-and-catalog-management.md).
- WHEN a product is withdrawn or deactivated by a seller, THE system SHALL update catalog state, remove purchase or cart eligibility, and retain change history snapshot for audit.
- WHEN an administrator modifies category, section, or structural attributes, THE system SHALL cascade business rule compliance revalidation on all associated products.

### Order Creation, Checkout, and Fulfillment
- WHERE a customer places an order, THE system SHALL validate product existence, price, availability, seller status, and that inventory is sufficient, considering minimum and maximum per-customer and per-SKU purchase limits.
- WHEN an order is submitted, THE system SHALL prevent duplicate submissions or accidental double ordering by invalidating repeated attempts within a protected session window.
- IF item availability changes between cart and checkout (e.g., stock reduced, option no longer valid), THEN THE system SHALL block checkout, present updated availability to the customer, and allow adjustment of the cart.
- WHILE an order is in defined modifiable states (e.g., prior to shipment), THE system SHALL allow only permitted field edits (address, contact, payment method) and block action if current status prohibits it.
- WHERE multi-vendor or split fulfillment applies, THE system SHALL maintain atomicity of each sub-order lifecycle, ensuring global order state accuracy (review [Order & Cart Management](./05-order-and-cart-management.md)).

### Review, Inquiry, and Community Content
- WHEN a customer submits a review, inquiry, or community post, THE system SHALL check eligibility (purchase completed, return window, policy criteria), enforce minimum/maximum content length, restrict use of banned/prohibited keywords, and snapshot each version.
- IF spam, fraudulent, or prohibited reviews/inquiries are detected (multi-account, automated posting, repeated abuse, or content matching banlists), THEN THE system SHALL suspend user content privileges, flag account for admin review, and record all infractions.
- WHERE content has attachment (image, file, doc), THE system SHALL enforce file type, size, and security scans as in [Attachment and File Management](./09-attachment-and-file-management.md), log all uploads/downloads, notify owner and admin of violations, and restrict sharing on policy breach or violation.
- WHEN moderation or legal review is performed, THE system SHALL snapshot all edits, removals, and moderator actions for evidence and compliance.

---

## 3. Data Integrity: Snapshots and Audit Trails

### State Change Recording and Version History
- WHEN any entity (order, product, review, user status, coupon, payout, attachment) changes state or content, THE system SHALL capture a complete, versioned, immutable snapshot including actor, timestamp, data before/after, and business rationale.
- THE system SHALL maintain exhaustive change/audit history per entity for the longer of minimum legal, regulatory, or self-imposed business policy duration (not less than 2 years unless longer required).
- WHERE admin-initiated edits or rollbacks occur, THE system SHALL log the full before/after diff, actor, and reason, and restrict further changes until secondary approval if required by workflow.
- IF external data (logistics, payment, settlement, evidence) drives update, THEN THE system SHALL record input provenance, correlation keys, and trace external update to business object.

### Traceability and Tamper Evidence
- THE system SHALL provide fine-grained traceability for all business-impacting operations, enabling complete reconstruction of entity lifecycles, legal evidence, and compliance monitoring on request from authorized roles.
- IF tampering, unauthorized manipulation, or out-of-sequence changes are detected in audit logs, THEN THE system SHALL automatically alert risk and compliance admins, lock impacted entities, escalate incident, and begin policy-driven investigation or remediation.

### Audit Trail Data Output and Legal Hold
- WHEN authorized administrators request audit log output for any entity, timespan, or event, THE system SHALL generate/export a complete record, apply role-based data redaction for protected user fields, and log all access for compliance review.
- WHERE a legal/administrative hold or dispute is declared, THE system SHALL prohibit destruction, overwriting, or anonymization until event is cleared/released as per legal or contractual rules.
- WHEN retention windows expire and no legal hold exists, THE system SHALL purge or archive data per data destruction and privacy policy, capturing process evidence in audit trail.

---

## 4. Coupon, Order, and Inventory Policies

### Coupon and Discount Issuance, Management, and Redemption
- WHEN a coupon or discount is created by eligible user (administrator, seller), THE system SHALL validate configured rules: role eligibility, validity term, application scope, redemption limits, stacking policy, and required business record linkage.
- WHEN issued, each coupon SHALL be individually tracked by serial, unique code, and redemptions per user/coupon, enforcing per-policy maximums and usage status.
- IF a coupon is redeemed outside eligibility window, by unauthorized actor, or in an unsupported context (wrong product, user group, date), THEN THE system SHALL block redemption, log the event with code/cause, and present explicit guidance to user.
- WHERE coupon stacking or combination with other discounts is specified (allowed or forbidden), THE system SHALL enforce the stacking/combination rule at order calculation every time and record which rules applied.

### Inventory Updates and Consistency
- WHEN an order is created or canceled, THE system SHALL atomically update related inventory balances, prevent negative inventory, and log the before/after count, responsible user, and reason for adjustment.
- IF an inventory discrepancy is detected (manual audit, sync, external integration), THEN THE system SHALL block order placement or fulfillment for affected SKUs, flag the product and correlated orders as pending review, and notify sellers and administrators.
- WHERE inventory is distributed among sellers, channels, or physical warehouses, THE system SHALL track each location, prevent aggregate/item-level oversell, and report low-stock thresholds for reordering or market actions.

### Order and Payment Finalization
- WHERE payment completion is required before accepting an order, THE system SHALL enforce no advancement of order state/status (e.g., to 'confirmed' or 'in fulfillment') prior to successful payment confirmation.
- IF payment fails (rejection, timeout, expiry, fraud hold), THEN THE system SHALL cancel the pending order, restore all held inventory, release coupon usage/discounts back to eligible state, and inform all parties (customer, seller, admin) with actionable status and next steps.
- WHEN refunds, reversals, or chargebacks occur, THE system SHALL update order/coupon/inventory records in real-time for absolute consistency and complete audit trail.

---

## 5. Refund, Cancellation, and Return Policies

### Order Cancellation
- WHEN a customer requests cancellation, THE system SHALL allow only if order status is eligible (pre-shipment, no hand-off to carrier), and require a user-provided reason with timestamped record.
- IF cancellation eligibility is not met (already shipped/delivered, fulfillment in progress), THEN THE system SHALL block the request and provide business-specific rationale and escalation options (refund, after-service, support).
- WHERE a seller initiates post-shipping cancellation against policy, THE system SHALL log the breach, record cause, and trigger compensatory workflows (e.g., refund, penalty, customer notification), as in [Performance, Error Handling, and Usability](./11-performance-error-handling-and-usability.md).

### Refund Processing
- WHEN a refund is requested (customer-initiated or after return/AS), THE system SHALL validate refund eligibility based on payment success, good/item received confirmation, product return (with condition/document evidence if required), and within policy-defined time frame.
- IF a refund is ineligible or documentation is missing/invalid, THEN THE system SHALL deny request, return clear rationale, and record attempt for escalation.
- WHEN a refund is approved, THE system SHALL calculate amount strictly according to total paid, deducting any unrefundable charges (shipping, coupon, event), referencing all applicable discounts as defined in [Discounts, Payments and Financial Flows](./06-discounts-payments-and-financial-flows.md), and produce real-time audit trail for each calculation step.
- IF a refund is delayed past policy deadline, THEN THE system SHALL auto-escalate to administrator for investigation and compensation flow.

### Return Handling, Abuse, and Fraud
- WHEN a customer requests return, THE system SHALL validate item/order eligibility (product, status, window, policy), require photographic or documentary evidence as stipulated, and log the request with chain-of-custody for the item.
- WHERE a return is accepted, THE system SHALL update order and inventory status, initiate the corresponding refund calculation, and log all events chronologically for compliance and audit.
- IF repetitive, abusive, or fraudulent return/refund activity is detected (over-persistent attempts, mismatched evidence, policy gamification), THEN THE system SHALL flag the account, restrict further returns temporarily, and escalate to administrators for final determination.
- WHEN return/refund is denied, THE system SHALL detail denial reason, log event, and allow customer to request appeal or escalation to support per policy.

---

## 6. Summary and Compliance

All business rules and domain logic for shoppingMallAi are specified in EARS format, ensuring they are complete, testable, and actionable. Requirements cover all roles, business flows, and error/performance scenarios, referencing linked domain documentation for context and detail. Technical architectural and implementation details are delegated fully to the development team, providing autonomy to determine APIs, schemas, and infrastructure. All referenced documents provide fuller definition of workflow, authentication, payment, and related policies for comprehensive development guidance.

# Performance, Error Handling, and Usability Requirements for shoppingMallAi

## 1. Performance Expectations (Response Time, Concurrency)

### Business Need
The shoppingMallAi platform must provide a seamless user experience at all times. Business success depends on responsiveness during high-traffic events (flash sales, promotions) and routine operations (checkout, authentication).

### Response Time Requirements (EARS)
- WHEN a customer performs a product search, THE system SHALL return search results within 2 seconds for 95% of queries.
- WHEN a user (any role) submits login credentials, THE system SHALL validate and respond within 2 seconds.
- WHEN a customer initiates checkout, THE system SHALL process the order and return a success/failure response within 3 seconds.
- WHEN a seller or administrator accesses dashboards or analytical data, THE system SHALL load reports within 5 seconds.
- WHEN system background jobs (inventory sync, batch processing) are triggered, THE system SHALL complete each batch within 15 minutes.

### Concurrency and Scalability (EARS)
- THE platform SHALL support a minimum of 10,000 concurrent users performing basic actions (browsing, search, checkout).
- WHEN concurrent traffic exceeds baseline, THE system SHALL shed non-critical background load to preserve transaction performance.
- WHERE high-volume sales events occur, THE system SHALL scale resources to maintain response times as specified above.

### Performance Monitoring (EARS)
- THE system SHALL continuously monitor business-critical response times and trigger alerts if thresholds are exceeded.
- IF defined SLAs are breached, THEN THE system SHALL generate a high-priority incident log and notify administrators immediately.


## 2. Usability Standards

### Accessibility and Ease-of-Use (EARS)
- THE platform SHALL present all outcome messages and errors in clear, unambiguous business language for customers, sellers, and administrators.
- THE user interface SHALL support full keyboard navigation and support for screen readers, including meaningful error feedback.
- WHEN users make invalid submissions, THE system SHALL highlight the erroneous input and provide actionable guidance.
- THE platform SHALL employ consistent field labeling, help tooltips where necessary, and persistent context for navigation.
- WHILE system is processing any user action, THE system SHALL display progress or status feedback so users are not left uncertain.
- IF a process is expected to take >10 seconds, THEN THE system SHALL present an explicit status message to inform the user.

### Consistency and Support (EARS)
- THE system SHALL use standardized business error codes/descriptions across all surfaces (see Error Case Definitions).
- WHEN a critical issue impacts order completion or payment, THE system SHALL provide a dedicated "Need Help?" workflow guiding users to support or recovery options.


## 3. Error Case Definitions

### Common Error Scenarios (by Role/Process)

| Role         | Scenario                           | Error Type               | User Message Example                   |
|--------------|------------------------------------|--------------------------|----------------------------------------|
| Customer     | Login fails (wrong password)       | Validation               | "Incorrect username or password."     |
| Customer     | Payment gateway timeout            | System/External          | "Payment service unavailable. Try again later or contact support." |
| Seller       | Product registration (invalid price)| Business Rule            | "Product price must be a positive value." |
| Administrator| Batch sync fails                   | System                   | "Internal process error. Check admin logs or contact engineering." |
| Any          | Request missing required data      | Validation               | "A required field is missing."        |


### Error Handling Requirements (EARS)
- IF a user submits invalid data for any process, THEN THE system SHALL inform the user of the exact error, flag the invalid field(s), and prevent process continuation.
- IF a business rule (e.g., item purchase limit, price restriction) is violated, THEN THE system SHALL present the relevant rule and suggest remediation steps.
- IF errors are caused by external systems (payment, logistics), THEN THE system SHALL present standardized messages and provide guidance on next steps.
- IF a system exception occurs that prevents completion of a user action, THEN THE system SHALL log the error, present a non-technical error message, and offer contact information for support.
- WHERE users repeatedly trigger the same error within a session, THE system SHALL direct them to FAQs or support after the third failed attempt.


## 4. Exception Recovery Workflows

### Automated & Manual Error Recovery (EARS & Mermaid)

- WHEN checkout processing fails due to a temporary payment gateway error, THE system SHALL:  
    - Retry the transaction up to two additional times within 30 seconds.  
    - IF recovery fails, THEN inform the user and log the incident for review.
- WHEN seller product registration actions are interrupted (network loss, timeout), THE system SHALL save the partial process state for recovery.
- WHERE administrator batch jobs fail, THE system SHALL create an error event with context and notify relevant roles for intervention.

#### Example Recovery Flow (Checkout Failure)
```mermaid
graph LR
  subgraph "Checkout Flow"
    A["User Submits Order"] --> B["Initiate Payment Processing"]
    B --> C{"Payment Success?"}
    C --|"Yes"| D["Complete Order & Notify User"]
    C --|"No"| E["Retry up to 2 times"]
    E --> F{"Success on Retry?"}
    F --|"Yes"| D
    F --|"No"| G["Show Failure Message"]
    G --> H["Log Incident & Alert Support"]
  end
```

#### Example Recovery Flow (Product Registration)
```mermaid
graph LR
  subgraph "Product Registration Error"
    X["Seller Submits Product Data"] --> Y["Validate Business Rules"]
    Y --> Z{"All Valid?"}
    Z --|"Yes"| AA["Save Product Listing"]
    Z --|"No"| BB["Flag Invalid Fields & Show Error"]
    BB --> CC["Allow Correction & Resubmission"]
  end
```


## 5. Logging & Issue Escalation

### Logging Requirements (EARS)
- THE system SHALL log all business-impacting exceptions with sufficient context: user ID, action, timestamp, error type, and details required for troubleshooting.
- WHEN high-severity errors (checkout failure, data corruption, payment issues) occur, THE system SHALL escalate by notifying administrators via email and in-platform alert within 30 seconds.
- WHEN error rates exceed defined thresholds in any business process, THE system SHALL trigger immediate automated alerts and create an audit record for later analysis.
- FOR each failed order, THE system SHALL assign an incident ID visible to administrators for further tracking.
- WHERE privacy is a concern (PII, payment data), THE system SHALL redact sensitive user details in logs according to compliance standards.
- THE system SHALL store all error and incident logs for a minimum of 1 year and ensure retrieval is possible by authorized roles only.

### Issue Escalation (EARS)
- WHEN an error is unresolved after standard retries or customer support intervention, THE system SHALL escalate the issue to the administrator queue with all contextual data.
- WHERE manual intervention is required to resolve business or system issues, THE system SHALL provide a workflow for authorized roles (seller, administrator) to correct, reopen, or escalate the incident record.


## 6. References to Related Documents
- For additional process details, see the [Core Functional Requirements](./03-core-functional-requirements.md).
- For payment error and fraud management, consult the [Discounts, Payments, and Financial Flows](./06-discounts-payments-and-financial-flows.md).
- For attachment and upload error handling, reference the [Attachment and File Management](./09-attachment-and-file-management.md).
- Business rules relating to cancellations, refunds, and other critical failures are in the [Business Rules and Domain Logic](./10-business-rules-and-domain-logic.md).


---

# Integration & Extensibility Requirements for shoppingMallAi

## 1. Introduction & Purpose
All requirements pertaining to the integration of external systems, extensibility of core functionality, and future readiness for scalable modularization within the shoppingMallAi backend are detailed here. Integrations include, but are not limited to, authentication services, payment gateways, logistics providers, analytics partners, affiliate and SSO connections, and pluggable business logic modules. Modular extensibility ensures shoppingMallAi can adopt new capabilities, partners, and markets with minimal disruption. Each process is governed by clear, enforceable business logic, is described in EARS format, and is supported by actionable rules to allow backend teams to build, extend, and maintain a robust platform ecosystem.

## 2. External Service Authentication
### Overview
shoppingMallAi requires unified, secure, and standardized authentication across third-party platforms while preserving platform control, traceability, and security for all user roles.

### Supported Flows
- Social login for customers (e.g., Google, Facebook, Apple)
- Seller partner SSO (external merchant/affiliate portals)
- Organization/intranet SSO for administrators (IDP-based)
- Fallback internal authentication (email/password)

### EARS Requirements
- WHEN a customer uses social login, THE system SHALL redirect to the external provider and, upon success, SHALL create or link a customer profile with all necessary attributes and eligibility assignments.
- WHEN a seller logs in via affiliate SSO, THE system SHALL verify identity, permission scope, and assign merchant role, restricting actions according to platform policy.
- WHEN an administrator signs in using org SSO, THE system SHALL require multi-factor authentication and log all access events.
- IF any third-party authentication fails, THEN THE system SHALL deny platform access, display a precise error message, and log the technical and business reason.
- WHERE required by business policy, THE system SHALL allow fallback to email/password only for roles and flows specifically authorized.
- WHEN a third-party auth provider is added, updated, or deprecated, THE system SHALL record changes, audit assignment changes, and notify relevant roles of impact.

### Business Rules & Policy
- All external identity providers integrated with shoppingMallAi must pass a compliance review regarding data sovereignty, consent, session lifecycle, and audit data availability.
- Each authentication flow must enforce the session duration, refresh, and token structure described in [User Roles & Authentication Requirements](./02-user-roles-and-authentication.md).
- Role and permission mappings from external IDP must not grant privileges outside the defined permission matrix.
- Authentication failures (invalid token, revoked session) SHALL trigger multi-level alerts (user, administrator, audit logger) and require manual override only by administrators.
- Policy and workflow for introducing, updating, or removing providers, including admin review and roll-back.

## 3. Payment Gateway Integration
### Overview
shoppingMallAi supports a configurable set of payment gateways (e.g., credit card processors, e-wallets, open banking) for secure, auditable, real-time and offline payment handling. Only fully certified and regulated gateways are permitted.

### EARS Requirements
- WHEN a customer proceeds to payment, THE system SHALL transfer all order-relevant payment data to the selected gateway, receive and verify transaction results, and update order/payment state atomically.
- IF the payment is declined, fails, or is aborted by user/system, THEN THE system SHALL roll back provisional changes and immediately explain the error with status code, reason, and possible corrective actions.
- WHEN more than one payment option is enabled (e.g., e-wallet, credit card, bank transfer), THE system SHALL present all eligible options based on user, region, device, and order context, and record chosen method for analytics.
- WHEN a payment gateway is delayed (over 10 seconds), THE system SHALL transparently set the payment to pending, inform the user, and re-check at intervals until timeout or resolution.
- IF payment is flagged for fraud or regulatory review, THEN THE system SHALL block order fulfillment, notify both customer and admin, and document all steps for compliance.

### Business Rules
- Payment gateway onboarding must follow vendor risk/compliance checklists and contractual approval, subject to platform owner sign-off.
- Payment tokens and customer card data may never be stored by the platform, except via transparent gateway vaults as required by law.
- Refunds and chargebacks must use APIs if supported and match the original payment flow in terms of data field mapping, error codes, audit logs, and business workflow.
- Batch settlement and reconciliation logs must be downloadable/exportable by permitted admin users, using platform permission rules.

### Error Handling
- WHEN a payment API is unavailable, THE system SHALL offer retry once, then redirect to payment method selection with a detailed cause.
- IF suspicious payment activity is detected (failed attempts, high volume), THEN THE system SHALL rate-limit further payment attempts for that account/device and require identity verification before resumption, logging all events.

## 4. API/Platform Connectivity
### Overview
shoppingMallAi requires robust API-based data exchange and automation with partners, affiliates, logistics, and channel systems, ensuring all interfaces are secure, discoverable, and business-governed.

### EARS Requirements
- WHEN an external system calls a public API endpoint, THE system SHALL require authentication as defined by platform policy, enforce data contract validation, and respond only with permitted business data.
- WHERE a new integration exposes user/product/order/fulfillment APIs, THE system SHALL require version identifiers, endpoint documentation, and access monitoring.
- IF a request fails contract checks or is unauthorized, THEN THE system SHALL block, log, and alert relevant roles, returning compliant business error codes.
- WHEN new partner systems are onboarded, THE system SHALL provide technical onboarding flows, test sandbox environments, and require acceptance of data governance rules before allowing live traffic.

### Business Rules
- Only authorized roles may request or grant integration API keys, and all keys must be revoked upon role/account deactivation.
- REST and webhook push/pull operations are supported for core integrations (orders, product sync, inventory, fulfillment), with optional future support for GraphQL/gRPC as business needs demand.
- All API response payloads must redact or pseudonymize regulated personal data, as directed by compliance policies.
- API deprecation must follow a 90-day minimum notification period, including backward support and migration toolkits for affected partners.
- All API and data exchange endpoints must be discoverable to eligible partners via platform-controlled registry, including documentation, version, and role-based access rights.
- Detailed business process diagrams for all core API/data exchange flows are maintained in the [API/Platform Connectivity section].

### Supported Protocols & Endpoints (Business Perspective)
- REST for partner/channel communication and product, order, and inventory updates
- Webhook/Push for real-time event notifications (order events, delivery, status updates)
- Optional GraphQL/gRPC for future deep integration layers or high-throughput partners
- Specific endpoints include: partner inventory allocation, real-time price sync, shipment creation and status, affiliate referral and commission reporting, channel analytics.

## 5. Extensible Modules
### Overview
shoppingMallAi supports extensible business logic via pluggable modules, seller or partner-specific customizations, and on-demand provisioning of AI/GPT features (product recommendations, search, analytics), without breaking core flows or compliance monitoring.

### EARS Requirements
- WHEN a module/provider is registered, THE system SHALL require and validate a manifest describing business scope, data access, and supported integration events (life cycle: registration, activation, update, deactivation, retirement).
- WHERE a module requests or requires access to elevated privileges (payments, customer data, internal APIs), THE system SHALL require explicit administrator approval and document the business justification.
- IF a module fails to initialize or causes business errors, THEN THE system SHALL automatically isolate, roll back all mutable changes, log incident, and inform permitted admin users.
- WHEN a module is updated (version bump, integration of new feature), THE system SHALL run compatibility and permission tests and suspend deployment if any required contract fails.
- WHERE a partner, AI, or analytics module is deprecated, THE system SHALL retain audit logs for a policy-defined retention period and remove all unneeded integration points.

### Business Rules
- Only permitted users (sellers and administrators) may request/enable modules or plug-ins for their scope; all global modules require administrator approval.
- All modules must operate within permission boundaries defined in the module manifest and matching the platform role matrix.
- Each module's registration/activation/deactivation/retirement state is auditable and reversible by permitted administrators.
- Module catalogues must expose public and proprietary modules separately, providing business/legal and feature data for each.
- All module errors, risk signals, and life cycle events must be visible to relevant roles in the admin dashboard, using business-centric event codes, and be available for export as CSV/Excel for compliance audits.
- Use cases: addition of dynamic pricing logic, external AI for personalization, logistics/shipping provider plug-ins, affiliate commission engines, language translation for new markets.

## 6. Versioning & Backward Compatibility
### Overview
All integration APIs, module interfaces, and data contracts require business-driven versioning and strict compatibility management.

### EARS Requirements
- WHEN a new version of any business contract, API, or module is released, THE system SHALL notify all affected roles, maintain backward compatibility for a minimum of 12 months, and publish deprecation and migration guidance.
- IF a breaking change is required and cannot be avoided, THEN THE system SHALL provide a business-led upgrade path, migration toolkit, and support resources at least 90 days before enforcement.
- WHERE multiple active versions of an integration/module exist, THE system SHALL route partner/customer requests to the requested or eligible version, in compliance with policy.
- WHEN a version reaches end-of-life, THE system SHALL archive or migrate all data as specified by business rules and inform all impacted parties in advance.

### Business Rules
- APIs/modules must be tagged and documented in the public/private partner portal, including affected business areas, supported versions, and sunset schedules.
- All legacy/archived versions must remain accessible for audit/statistics but blocked for new connections or changes.
- Version conflicts, schema drift, and backward-compatibility disputes must be escalated to a dedicated platform admin, using business rationale and recorded in the operational log.

## 7. Business Scenarios & Use Cases

### Scenario 1: New Logistics Partner API Integration
WHEN a new logistics company is selected, THE system SHALL require a partnership agreement, register the API, run test order and fulfillment events, and audit compliance and latency before production enabling. Key steps: onboarding, credentials/testing, data mapping, simulation runs, role approval, live launch, ongoing monitoring, and evidence retention.

### Scenario 2: Seller Deploys Custom Analytics Module
WHEN a seller opts for analytics/personalization plug-in, THE system SHALL validate credentials, assign scope (i.e., only to the seller’s own products), sandbox all data, and restrict API visibility to business objects and actions allowed by role. Feedback loop and error handling must be auditable, reversible, and explainable from a business process perspective.

### Scenario 3: Affiliate Referral and Commission Reporting Integration
WHEN an affiliate initiates integration, THE system SHALL require business registration, compliance check, map payout logic, enable commission workflow, provide performance portal, and subject all actions to audit and approval. Role-based business rules must govern commission triggers, payment cycles, fraud detection, and access rights.

### Scenario 4: AI-Powered Personalization API Extension
WHEN an administrator enables a new AI-powered recommendation engine, THE system SHALL require module registration, approval of data access and personalization scope, and provide role-based UI and reporting. All model learning data, audit events, and configuration changes must be accessible to administrators and auditable for compliance.

### Scenario 5: Emergency Provider Deactivation and Failover
IF a payment gateway or logistics integration is compromised (security, business, legal), THEN THE system SHALL immediately isolate the provider, queue pending transactions, reroute eligible traffic to alternative channels, and notify all users/administrators. Allowed failover actions and user/business notification flows must be clearly documented.

## 8. Business Rules, Performance & Error Handling

### Integration-Specific Business Policy
- All integration onboarding, offboarding, and role mapping processes must be governed by clear business workflows, including dynamic approval, version compatibility, policy update triggers, and multi-role notifications.
- Integrations can be initiated, reviewed, modified, and withdrawn only by roles and users with explicit platform rights, as described in the permissions matrix below. Unauthorized activity leads to immediate suspension and alert escalation.
- All real-time event integrations (e.g., payments, AI recommendations) must meet end-user-perceived latency requirements (see Performance & SLAs below).
- Administrative dashboards must provide filtering, export, and bulk-action tools for integration management, error review, and compliance documentation.
- Full auditability and traceability is required for all integration-related business and error events. Data and event logs must be retained per legal/business policy.

### Performance & SLAs (EARS Format)
- WHEN any authentication, payment, or mission-critical integration is invoked, THE system SHALL complete user-facing business operations (auth, payment confirmation, event notification) within 3 seconds for 95% of interactions under normal load.
- WHEN a batch integration process (nightly sync, analytics update) is triggered, THE system SHALL guarantee completion within defined schedule, notify all dependent users of window and exceptions, and escalate on failure.
- WHEN an error threshold (rate/volume) is crossed for any integration, THE system SHALL immediately log the event, flag affected roles, and trigger a support team notification and require periodic status updates until resolved.

### Error & Exception Handling (EARS Format)
- IF a partner or platform integration action (API, payment, module event) fails for any business reason, THEN THE system SHALL provide precise user/admin feedback, log the event with business context, and offer remediation or failover workflow.
- IF an integration returns a non-business-compliant or unrecognized status, THEN THE system SHALL alert affected roles and administrators, flag as “pending manual review”, and record the complete business, technical, and partner-specific details.
- IF a platform administrator explicitly revokes an integration/module for compliance or emergency, THEN THE system SHALL terminate all active session tokens, queue pending transactions, inform all users, and escalate the event with required report generation and evidence collection.
- IF integration-induced failures impact user experience (delayed payments, data sync issues), THEN THE system SHALL preserve all pending actions, retry according to policy, and inform all affected users with guidance on next step and estimated recovery windows.

## 9. Diagrams & Tables

### Integration Flow (Mermaid Diagram)
```mermaid
graph LR
  subgraph "User Interaction"
    A["Customer Initiates Checkout"]
    B["Seller Performs Bulk Product Sync"]
  end
  subgraph "Integration Layer"
    C["Auth/Payment API Adapter"]
    D["AI Personalization Module"]
    E["3rd Party Logistics Connector"]
  end
  subgraph "External Systems"
    F["Payment Gateway"]
    G["Social Login Provider"]
    H["Logistics API"]
  end
  A --> C
  B --> D
  C --> F
  C --> G
  D --> E
  E --> H
```

### Permissions Matrix
| Action/Feature                        | Customer | Seller                | Administrator     |
|---------------------------------------|----------|----------------------|-------------------|
| Use social/3rd-party login            | ✅       | ✅ (partner SSO)     | ✅ (org SSO)      |
| Initiate outbound API connections     | ❌       | ✅                   | ✅                |
| Register/modify integrations          | ❌       | ✅ (limited/self)    | ✅ (full)         |
| Approve/revoke 3rd-party modules      | ❌       | ❌                  | ✅                |
| Monitor/log integration errors        | ❌       | ✅ (own modules)     | ✅ (all)          |
| Access payment gateway for order      | ✅       | ✅                   | ✅                |
| Manage version & migration policies   | ❌       | ❌                  | ✅                |
| Request analytics/AI module use       | ❌       | ✅                   | ✅                |
| Access compliance/audit dashboards    | ❌       | ❌                  | ✅                |

## 10. References
- For overall business model, objectives, and AI vision, see the [Service Vision & Business Model Document](./01-service-vision-and-business-model.md).
- For authentication/SSO design, user role control, and permissions, consult the [User Roles & Authentication Requirements](./02-user-roles-and-authentication.md).
- For product catalog, order, and payment core requirements, see [Core Functional Requirements](./03-core-functional-requirements.md).

# Glossary

## User Roles & Permissions

- **customer**: General shoppers and buyers who can register, browse, purchase products, manage orders, use coupons/mileage, create reviews and inquiries, and maintain personal accounts. May interact as guest, member, or via external services. 
  - WHEN a customer registers, THE system SHALL allow product browsing, purchasing, account management, coupon/mileage use, review/inquiry creation, and personal information maintenance.
  - IF a guest customer attempts a restricted action (e.g., making a purchase), THEN THE system SHALL prompt account creation or login.
- **seller**: Vendors authorized to list, update, and manage products, handle orders, monitor sales and performance metrics, respond to inquiries, issue coupons, and access analytics relevant to their merchandise. Requires verification and administrator approval.
  - WHEN a seller is verified and approved, THE system SHALL allow product and order management, performance analytics access, and customer interaction regarding their offerings.
- **administrator**: System operators with full privileges over user management, seller verification, product/category orchestration, policy enforcement, content moderation, issue resolution, analytics oversight, and platform maintenance.
  - THE administrator SHALL have unrestricted access to all business, monitoring, and management features across the platform.
- **role-based permissions**: The set of operations permitted or forbidden for each role; strictly enforced through all workflows. Differentiates actions available to customers, sellers, and administrators.
- **permission matrix**: Tabular or formal mapping showing for each role which functions are allowed or denied by business policy (see [User Roles & Authentication Requirements](./02-user-roles-and-authentication.md)).

## Key Business Objects

- **product**: A purchasable item listed by a seller, containing name, description, pricing, images, variants, options, inventory information, and associated metadata.
- **order**: A transactional record representing a customer's confirmed purchase, including ordered items, shipping, payment details, status history, and fulfillment progress.
- **cart**: The virtual mechanism gathering selected products for potential purchase in the same checkout session, maintained per customer or guest user.
- **coupon**: A digital certificate (code or token) providing predefined discounts or benefits when validated and redeemed under applicable conditions.
- **deposit/mileage**: Prepaid balance or reward-accumulating points, granted to customers for specific actions or as compensation, usable for partial or full payment for future orders.
- **review**: Customer-created content evaluating a product or purchase experience. May feature ratings, text, images, and is subject to moderation and edit tracking.
- **inquiry**: Customer-submitted question or issue to a seller or operator regarding a product, order, or general site function. Managed with reply history and evidence preservation.
- **category**: Logical grouping of products (e.g., Electronics, Apparel) to aid navigation and search. Categories may be multi-level/hierarchical.
- **section/channel**: Subset of the platform dedicated to specific business purposes, brands, sellers, or external affiliates, sometimes reflecting separate stores under one system.
- **snapshot/history**: Timestamped record of changes for mutable business objects (e.g., product edits, order updates), essential for audit trails and regulatory compliance.

## Processes & Workflows

- **registration**: The process by which a user (customer or seller) creates an account on the platform, requiring input such as personal data, email/credentials, and acceptance of policies.
- **authentication**: The act of verifying user identity, typically via login credentials, OAuth, or SSO, to assign proper permissions and maintain session integrity.
- **product listing**: Seller-driven process of registering new products to the platform, specifying attributes, images, price, inventory, and category mapping.
- **order creation**: Multi-step workflow: customer reviews products, adds to cart, enters delivery/payment details, agrees to policies, and confirms purchase, creating an order.
- **payment**: Secure exchange whereby the platform validates funds, processes payment (card, deposit, coupon, etc.), issues receipts, and triggers fulfillment.
- **fulfillment**: Seller/system workflow of preparing, shipping, and confirming delivery of purchased items, including returns, exchanges, and after-service support.
- **moderation**: Administrator or seller review and management of customer-contributed content, complaints, or suspected abuse (reviews, inquiries), can include editing, approval, or sanctioning.
- **customer support**: Channel for users to resolve issues, request refunds, make complaints, or get technical/business assistance. Integrated with inquiry and evidence processes.

## Channel/Section Definitions

- **channel**: A business, marketing, or distribution context (e.g., in-house, affiliate partner, B2B, B2C) represented as a logically separated segment. May control product visibility, pricing, and business rules.
- **section**: Usually refers to a sub-area of the e-commerce site or a sub-store devoted to a particular brand, seller, or category, implementing specific features, themes, or content policies.
- **storefront**: Public-facing virtual shopfront aggregating visible products accessible by customers. Can contain multiple sections or be part of a larger channel.
- **multi-store environment**: The ability for the backend to manage several distinct stores, brands, or sellers under one unified platform, with individualized policies and data segregation.

## AI/ML Concepts

- **AI personalization**: The system’s use of artificial intelligence to tailor the user experience, such as recommending products or customizing deals based on behavioral data and purchase patterns.
- **recommendation engine**: An AI-driven tool generating personalized product/content recommendations, based on customer data, crowd insights, contextual information, and business rules.
- **dynamic pricing**: A strategy in which AI algorithms adjust product prices automatically in real-time, reacting to demand signals, inventory status, seasonality, or user profile.
- **fraud detection**: Use of AI/ML models to identify, prevent, or flag abnormal and potentially fraudulent activities within transactions, user behavior, or content submissions.
- **sentiment analysis**: AI-driven interpretation of user-generated reviews, inquiries, and feedback to determine emotions, satisfaction levels, and actionable business insights.
- **analytics**: The set of data-driven processes, including AI and statistical techniques, to aggregate, analyze, and visualize business/performance/user data for strategic decision-making. Includes operational dashboards and real-time metrics for sellers and administrators.

---

All terms in this glossary are provided exclusively in the context of the shoppingMallAi backend service. For detailed, role-specific permissions, process diagrams, or requirements, please refer to the [User Roles & Authentication Requirements](./02-user-roles-and-authentication.md) and related specification documents.

# Appendices for shoppingMallAi Platform

This appendix presents comprehensive reference data, business-side flow diagrams, and supplementary information essential for the implementation and understanding of the shoppingMallAi backend business requirements. It is designed to provide stakeholders—including backend developers and business operators—with actionable visualizations, role matrices, and summary aids that supplement core requirement documents. Every table and diagram is carefully explained to ensure clarity of backend permissions, business workflows, and operational boundaries.

## 1. Reference Tables & Matrices

### 1.1 User Roles and Permissions Matrix

The matrix below clarifies which core actions each role can perform. All permissions correspond to the business workflows described in the requirements documents. Where a permission is listed as "✅" for a role, the role may perform the full business process; otherwise, access is denied and the system enforces this by returning a clear, actionable error (see EARS error rules in main requirements).

| Action/Feature                                   | Customer | Seller | Administrator |
|--------------------------------------------------|----------|--------|---------------|
| Register account                                 | ✅       | ✅    | ❌            |
| Browse/search products                           | ✅       | ✅    | ✅            |
| Purchase products                                | ✅       | ❌    | ✅            |
| Manage personal orders and returns               | ✅       | ❌    | ✅            |
| Write product reviews/inquiries                  | ✅       | ❌    | ✅            |
| Issue/manage products & listings                 | ❌       | ✅    | ✅            |
| Manage incoming orders on own listings           | ❌       | ✅    | ✅            |
| Track sales performance, coupons, analytics      | ❌       | ✅    | ✅            |
| Moderate content (reviews, inquiries, listings)  | ❌       | ❌    | ✅            |
| Access business analytics dashboard              | ❌       | ✅    | ✅            |
| Verify and approve seller onboarding             | ❌       | ❌    | ✅            |
| Manage user/seller accounts                      | ❌       | ❌    | ✅            |
| Change platform/system settings                  | ❌       | ❌    | ✅            |

**Permission Edge Cases and Business Rules:**
- IF a user (of any role) attempts an action that is not permitted (e.g., a customer tries to manage product listings), THEN THE system SHALL reject the action and provide a business reason in the error response.
- IF a seller attempts to access another seller's data, THEN THE system SHALL block access even when the action would otherwise be allowed for "seller" on their own listings.
- WHEN administrators act, they may override or audit other roles but must comply with logged business audit trails for any such intervention.
- Where permissions are limited to "own data" (e.g., 'Manage incoming orders on own listings'), enforce ownership at all validation stages.

### 1.2 Order Lifecycle States Matrix

This matrix outlines each business-recognized order state and clarifies the transitions and stakeholder expectations at every point in the purchase lifecycle. State transitions correspond to the system processes described in the order management requirements.

| Order State            | Description                                                    |
|-----------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------|
| CART                  | Order items reside in cart and can be updated/removed           |
| PENDING_PAYMENT       | Order placed, awaiting payment                                  |
| PAID                  | Payment received successfully                                   |
| PROCESSING            | Seller preparing order for shipment                             |
| SHIPPED               | Order dispatched, tracking available                            |
| DELIVERED             | Customer receives order                                         |
| CANCELED              | Order canceled by user, seller, or admin                        |
| RETURN_REQUESTED      | Customer requested return/refund                                |
| RETURNED              | Order returned, refund in process                              |
| COMPLETED             | Order lifecycle finished, eligible for review                   |

**State Transition Notes:**
- WHEN a state transition fails validation or business logic (e.g., marking as "PAID" without valid payment), THEN THE system SHALL refuse the state change and notify all affected stakeholders with actionable reasons.
- WHERE multiple sellers and split orders are involved, the parent order state reflects the aggregate state, while sub-orders track individual flows.
- IF an order is canceled after shipment, return and refund rules trigger automatically as per business logic in primary requirements.

### 1.3 Discount and Coupon Types Table

Discounts and coupon incentives form part of the business’s pricing, sales, and marketing strategies. The table clarifies scope, typical issuers, and business-side usage restrictions. All coupon/discount application follows rule-based validation (EARS in requirements document).

| Coupon/Discount Type       | Applicable Scope           | Issuer      | Usage Restrictions         |
|---------------------------|----------------------------|-------------|---------------------------|
| Product Coupon            | Individual product         | Seller      | Single product only        |
| Cart Coupon               | Entire cart                | Seller/Admin| Min. purchase threshold    |
| Percent Discount          | Product/order/cart         | Seller/Admin| Often capped, by config    |
| Shipping Coupon           | Shipping fees              | Seller/Admin| May have region limits     |
| Loyalty Points/Mileage    | Platform-wide              | System      | Limited by balance         |
| Event/Special             | Event/seasonal products    | Seller/Admin| Valid only for event term  |

**Business Clarification and Edge Cases:**
- IF a coupon is submitted outside its valid window or context, THEN THE system SHALL reject redemption and specify the relevant EARS error (e.g., COUPON_EXPIRED, INELIGIBLE_ORDER).
- WHEN a user tries to combine non-stackable discounts, THE system SHALL validate stacking constraints before order finalization.
- Each coupon/discount must be auditable and traceable to the issuing party and must comply with global and per-user redemption ceilings.

### 1.4 File Attachment Type Table

The business context of each file type is defined below, indicating responsible roles and mandatory business validations. File handling policies are elaborated in the [Attachment and File Management Requirements](./09-attachment-and-file-management.md).

| Attachment Context        | File Type Examples          | Key Rules                                   |
|-------------------------|-----------------------------|---------------------------------------------|
| Product Listing         | JPG, PNG                    | Max size per image, preview generation      |
| Review/Inquiry          | PNG, JPG, PDF               | Evidence uploads must be moderated          |
| Identity Verification   | PDF, JPG                    | Restricted access, secure storage required  |
| Seller Business Docs    | PDF, JPG                    | Only for administrators, audit trails kept  |

**File Management & Compliance Notes:**
- IF a file is uploaded with the wrong format or outside configured limits, THEN THE system SHALL flag the action, inform the uploader, and require immediate correction.
- WHERE files are business-critical (e.g., seller onboarding), THE system SHALL require successful upload before process completion.
- Ownership, access control, and retention are strictly governed—see [Attachment and File Management Requirements](./09-attachment-and-file-management.md) for process EARS.

## 2. Business Flow Diagrams

The diagrams in this section visualize mission-critical business processes. Each flow is fully compliant with strict Mermaid syntax—ALL labels use double quotes, there are no spaces outside brackets and quotes, and no arrows use invalid notations. Each is accompanied by business logic commentary clarifying workflow expectations for backend developers.

### 2.1 User Registration and Authentication Flow

New user creation and entry into the system must validate identity, ensure data completeness, and support confirmation workflows for compliance. Business rules enforce verification at every decision point.

```mermaid
graph LR
  subgraph "User Auth Flow"
    A["User Starts Registration"] --> B["Input Email/Password/Social Account"]
    B --> C["System Validates Input"]
    C --> D{"Valid?"}
    D -->|"Yes"| E["Account Creation"]
    D -->|"No"| F["Show Error Message"]
    E --> G["Send Verification Email/SMS"]
    G --> H{"User Confirms?"}
    H -->|"Yes"| I["Complete Registration"]
    H -->|"No"| J["Await User Action"]
    I --> K["Login Enabled"]
  end
```

WHEN required registration data is incomplete or fails validation, THE system SHALL block account creation and return top-level error details with guidance for correction. All successful registrations trigger verification and status controls before login is enabled, maintaining auditability throughout the process.

### 2.2 Order and Payment Processing Flow

Order creation and payment flows are pivotal to business health, combining customer input, system validations, payment handling, and post-purchase activities. Parallel processes for fulfillment and customer notification are embedded.

```mermaid
graph LR
  subgraph "Order/Payment Process"
    AA["User Adds Item to Cart"] --> AB["Review Cart"]
    AB --> AC["Proceed to Checkout"]
    AC --> AD["Input Shipping & Payment"]
    AD --> AE["System Validates Details"]
    AE --> AF{"Valid?"}
    AF -->|"Yes"| AG["Attempt Payment"]
    AF -->|"No"| AH["Show Input Error"]
    AG --> AI{"Payment Success?"}
    AI -->|"Yes"| AJ["Confirm Order, Issue Invoice"]
    AI -->|"No"| AK["Show Payment Error"]
    AJ --> AL["Notify Seller"]
    AL --> AM["Order Processing by Seller"]
    AM --> AN["Ship Item"]
    AN --> AO["Track/Update Order Status"]
    AO --> AP["Delivery Complete"]
    AP --> AQ["Post-Purchase: Review, Return Option"]
  end
```

WHEN payment fails or order validation triggers a business logic error, THE system SHALL log the failure, return actionable feedback, and ensure atomic state handling for cart, order, and payment data. Successful payment always leads to downstream fulfillment and customer notification; any substantial delays or exceptions must be visible at each business step.

### 2.3 Product Catalog Workflow

Catalog management enables sellers to maintain their digital storefronts while ensuring quality and compliance through administrator review. State transitions ensure only valid, approved products reach customers.

```mermaid
graph LR
  subgraph "Catalog Management"
    BA["Seller Logs In"] --> BB["List New Product or Edit Existing"]
    BB --> BC["Input Product Details/Images"]
    BC --> BD["Select Category/Options"]
    BD --> BE["System Validates Data"]
    BE --> BF{"Approved by Admin?"}
    BF -->|"Yes"| BG["Product Published"]
    BF -->|"No"| BH["Admin Feedback to Seller"]
    BH --> BB
    BG --> BI["Visible to Shoppers"]
  end
```

Product submissions that fail business or data validation, or are denied by admins, are rerouted for re-edit, with explicit business feedback given for correction and resubmission. Products become eligible for public display only after successful multi-stage verification and compliance review. Every catalog transaction is fully audited, with change histories accessible for dispute or legal checks.

### 2.4 Community Review and Inquiry Workflow

Customer-generated content is a vital business asset, but must balance openness and moderation to protect platform integrity.

```mermaid
graph LR
  subgraph "Review/Inquiry Flow"
    CA["Customer Purchases Product"] --> CB["Eligible for Review/Inquiry"]
    CB --> CC["Submit Review or Inquiry"]
    CC --> CD["System Moderates Content"]
    CD --> CE{"Compliant?"}
    CE -->|"Yes"| CF["Publish to Product Page"]
    CE -->|"No"| CG["Flag/Rework Submission"]
    CG --> CC
  end
```

WHEN user submissions breach business rules (inappropriate content, non-purchase review attempts, suspicious attachments), THE system SHALL route cases for moderation, loop back for user correction, or enforce denial and escalation to administrators according to the business escalation chain. All actions and status changes are logged and reviewable for compliance.

## 3. Supplementary Materials

### 3.1 Glossary Reference

Detailed terminology—including all user and system role definitions, business logic concepts, and key process flows—is provided in the [Platform Glossary](./13-glossary.md). WHEN a term is not understood or causes contest, THE system SHALL reference the glossary to standardize process language across all business and technical stakeholders.

### 3.2 Key Success Metrics Table

Key performance indicators express critical business outcomes and operational health. Developers and operators must use these metrics to guide design and respond to business change.

| KPI Name              | Description                                         | Typical Target         | Business Impact                                     |
|-----------------------|-----------------------------------------------------|-----------------------|-----------------------------------------------------|
| Monthly Active Users  | Unique users engaged monthly                        | 10,000+               | Measures adoption and engagement rate               |
| Gross Merchandise Volume (GMV) | Total value of goods sold through platform    | $X million/month      | Indicates revenue throughput and marketplace scale  |
| Conversion Rate       | % of visitors making purchases                      | >2%                   | Assesses effectiveness of sales funnel              |
| Repeat Purchase Rate  | % of orders from repeat buyers                      | >30%                  | Tracks customer loyalty & business retention        |
| Average Resolution Time| Avg. time to handle inquiries/issues                | <24h                  | Indicates support responsiveness and satisfaction   |
| Seller Onboarding Speed| Avg. time to full seller live status                | <5 days               | Reflects seller-facing business efficiency          |

WHEN performance or engagement metrics fall below target thresholds, THE business SHALL require root cause analysis and business-side process review, triggering improvements or optimizations in platform workflows as needed.

### 3.3 Additional Supplementary Notes

- WHEN backend business processes evolve to include new features, roles, or compliance requirements, THE appendix SHALL be updated to reflect any new matrices, flows, or KPIs relevant to ongoing operation.
- All reference documents are cross-linked using clear, descriptive text for seamless navigation and business alignment.
- For in-depth role and permission requirements: see [User Roles and Authentication Requirements](./02-user-roles-and-authentication.md)
- For transaction flows and state logic: see [Order and Cart Management Requirements](./05-order-and-cart-management.md)
- For product, catalog, and attachment policies: see [Product and Catalog Management Requirements](./04-product-and-catalog-management.md) and [Attachment and File Management Requirements](./09-attachment-and-file-management.md)

---

Every visual, matrix, and table in this appendix is crafted to support backend platform consistency, business scalability, compliance, and operational clarity. WHEN questions of workflow, permissions, or performance arise, backend developers SHALL reference these appendices to drive high-confidence, policy-aligned implementation. No implementation source code or technical schema is included by design—business requirements and operational clarity are the sole focus throughout.
